headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Back at Workspace, David, how much of a boost have you been getting from the Windows 10 transition, which is really getting towards its end? And are you at all concerned about incremental competition, the Desktop-as-a-Service market from either Azure or A
componenttext: Back at Workspace, David, how much of a boost have you been getting from the Windows 10 transition, which is really getting towards its end? And are you at all concerned about incremental competition, the Desktop-as-a-Service market from either Azure or AWS? And what's your strategy there?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Two things. I mean if you think about Windows 10, I mean, it's one of the drivers. I'd say that the platform drivers are less these days than they would have been 5 years ago, and that's simply because most of the use cases that I talk to customers a
componenttext: Yes. Two things. I mean if you think about Windows 10, I mean, it's one of the drivers. I'd say that the platform drivers are less these days than they would have been 5 years ago, and that's simply because most of the use cases that I talk to customers about tend to be around security or enabling mobility or enabling workforce productivity. It's those types of things. But it also includes platform evolution. So I'd say that, that's one of many. In terms of DaaS, we actually don't compete in DaaS today. We've announced that we are building a DaaS product on top of Azure virtual desktop, which we'll talk about a little bit later in the year. But it's a different category than we've competed in historically. And we do think it's important. That's one of the reasons why we're doing this natively on top of Microsoft. We're actually becoming a cloud service provider so that we can bundle certain capabilities in the infrastructure together with our solution, the idea to really focus on customer simplicity and simplification. And that's going to be our strategy going forward. We've been embracing and extending the Microsoft platform for 30 years now. I think we'll continue to do that, especially in new categories like DaaS that are just new opportunities going forward.

componenttext: Yes. Cash flow is the area that you're going to have to look at in conjunction with future committed revenue because our billing -- kind of our billing cycles are changing as we go through this. And it's the same as we've talked about for a long, long time. I mean as we go to book SaaS contracts, the typical contract is 3 years of total contract value annualized billings. And that's what's building this unbilled deferred that we're disclosing. [ In fact, ] unbilled increased by about $300 million year-over-year. In the historical model, we would have billed all that upfront. So it's just a timing conversation more than anything else. Remind everybody the total future committed revenue that was up to about $2.1 billion now, grew 21% year-on-year.

componenttext: This is Jerry Diao filling in for Phil. Congratulations on the strong first quarter. I just want to build upon Heather's question and your comments on how Workspace has evolved. Could you give some specific color on kind of what's precisely driving this re-acceleration in terms of whether it's sales re-engagement or just customer better understand the new functionality, et cetera?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q1 2019 Earnings Call, Apr 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jerry. I'd say it's very consistent with the strategy that we've been talking about now for 1.5 years, 2 years. It's about -- we're thinking about the Workspace much more broadly than simply virtualization. And that allows us to address really all c
componenttext: Sure, Jerry. I'd say it's very consistent with the strategy that we've been talking about now for 1.5 years, 2 years. It's about -- we're thinking about the Workspace much more broadly than simply virtualization. And that allows us to address really all customers in a way that we talk about as kind of general purpose. And what that means is it's the opportunity to expand beyond traditional virtualization in the installed base. And think about providing customers with a platform upon which automation, security, analytics can reside that provides value even to the users that have really light application use, including those that don't need any virtualization whatsoever. So all applications, all potential seats inside of an account really anywhere in the world, et cetera. And that overall core message is resonating with customers. And I think that's allowed us to reengage and start accelerating that business over the past couple of years.

Okay. Well, that was awfully quick. I guess the memo and the new format is doing its job by providing this incremental level of information that we're asking for. So I really just want to thank everyone, again, for joining us today. 
Overall, as I said, we're very happy with how the business performed in Q1 and expect to continue driving our subscription transition throughout the year. Hopefully, many of you are joining us at our annual Synergy Conference in May or at least tuning in, in June, to our analyst meeting. 
Thank you again. Talk to you soon.

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Ashley, and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Citrix Systems Second Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to introduce Ms. Traci Tsuchiguchi, Vice President of Investor Relations. You may begin your conference.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ashley. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for today's second quarter and fiscal year 2019 earnings call. Participating on the call will be David Henshall, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jessica Soisson, interim
componenttext:
Thank you, Ashley. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for today's second quarter and fiscal year 2019 earnings call. Participating on the call will be David Henshall, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jessica Soisson, interim Chief Financial Officer. Please note that we have posted our second quarter earnings memo to our Investor Relations website. 
I'd like to remind you that today's conversation will contain forward-looking statements made under the safe harbor provision of the U.S. securities law. These statements are based on current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties. Actual results could differ materially from those anticipated. Additional information concerning these and other factors are highlighted in today's earnings quarter and in the company's filings with the SEC. Copies are available from the SEC or on our Investor Relations website. 
Furthermore, we discuss various non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC's Regulation G. A reconciliation of the differences between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures discussed on today's call can be found at the end of our earnings letter found on the Investor Relations page of our website. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to David, our President and Chief Executive Officer. David?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Traci, and good afternoon. Thanks to everybody for joining the call. I hope everybody had an opportunity to review the earnings letter that we posted to our IR site. And similar to last quarter, I'm going to keep my opening remarks really brief so
componenttext:
Thanks, Traci, and good afternoon. Thanks to everybody for joining the call. I hope everybody had an opportunity to review the earnings letter that we posted to our IR site. And similar to last quarter, I'm going to keep my opening remarks really brief so we can jump right into Q&A, and I thought it would be important to provide a little bit of context of the business overall. 
So I think all in, we're really happy with our performance in the second quarter. Demand across our products and our geos was remarkably consistent throughout the quarter. The only real difference was mix. Now we clearly underestimated the demand for subscription licensing in the quarter. The subscription transition for new licensing is really happen faster than we forecasted across both of our major businesses, which is strategically where we're driving the company. 
We expected this accelerated pace will continue for the full year. The obvious consequence here of the faster shift is revenue, margins, earnings and cash flow are going to be impacted in the short term with the offset represented in unbilled and deferred revenue in particular. Just to be really clear here. So the mix shift explains in the entire difference between our reported second quarter results and our guidance. We have guided a midpoint mix of about 52%, and the actual was 62%. Within this result, we also saw a record subscription booking levels in both of our businesses. The Workspace product mix jumped up to 71% from 58 a year ago while Networking moved from 11% last year up to 35% in Q2. We'll talk more about the demand drivers once we get into the Q&A. 
It's important to point out again that for all of our financial statements going to be impacted by the business transition including cash flow because we typically bill annually for subscription contracts rather than everything upfront like we typically do in perpetual license deal so less cash is collected in the current period, more cash is going to be collected in future periods. So in other words, the strength that we're seeing in subscription bookings serve to improve our predictability and certainly accelerate our growth in future periods. And that's the primary reason why we've introduced future committed revenues, one of our new metrics. Hopefully, you saw that, that balance is now up to $2.2 billion. It's up $290 million or 15% from last year. It's the easiest way to just think about the transition. 
But to make the full year transition really simple for everybody, I'll just give you a quick rule of thumb, that is for every 1 percentage point change in mix, it's equal to roughly $10 million to $12 million in recognized revenue for a full year basis. This offset to the decrease in recognized revenue in the period is generally the corresponding increase to unbilled or deferred revenue. So that when you look at our full year guidance, we now expect the subscription mix of new product bookings of at least 60% to 65%. This compared to 50, 55 earlier. This is a change from our prior guidance to current guidance. 
Finally, this quarter, we are introducing ARR, or annualized recurring revenue, as probably the most important KPI for our business. The way we calculated this is a bottoms-up, contract-based metrics, which we believe is really the most important way to measure the performance in this transition. You'll see a 5-quarter history in our earnings letter. I'll point out for Q2, total subscription ARR was $614 million, and that's up 33% year-on-year while the SaaS-only ARR was $418 million, and that's up nearly 50% year-over-year. As we continue to move through the business model transformation, we expect to see very strong continued growth in both of these metrics. 
So let me stop there with that and turn it back over to the operator so that we can open it up and take your questions.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Raimo Lenschow with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Raimo Lenschow with Barclays.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: I know there's a lot of stuff to go through, David, like can you help us a little bit on what you see in terms of customers in terms of term and service provider versus like doing this as a SaaS offering in terms of like what do you see there Because I lo
componenttext: I know there's a lot of stuff to go through, David, like can you help us a little bit on what you see in terms of customers in terms of term and service provider versus like doing this as a SaaS offering in terms of like what do you see there Because I look at the numbers on my side it's more CSP and term is driving it but understand the dynamic there.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Only 2 things, Raimo. One, we're seeing strong growth across all 3 of those areas. Now you saw that SaaS-only ARR is the one that really ticked up. It's growing nearly 50% right now at a scale north of $400 million. So that is the cleanest representation
componenttext:
Only 2 things, Raimo. One, we're seeing strong growth across all 3 of those areas. Now you saw that SaaS-only ARR is the one that really ticked up. It's growing nearly 50% right now at a scale north of $400 million. So that is the cleanest representation in thinking about Citrix cloud. The other 2 businesses that show up in the other subscription you pointed out CSP, which for everybody is the consumption-based subscription that we have mostly through our partners. That business is north of $100 million run rate now, continues to grow nicely. 
And then the on-premise term, I'd say on-premise term is a bridge for a lot of customers as they're moving from a perpetual license to a true subscription. A lot of those tend to be hybrid licenses where they're working through the transition of their own interests infrastructure. Long term, we actually want to highlight much more SaaS-driven so on-prem term is a bridge in between the 2, but the fastest growing part of the business is pure SaaS.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Phil Winslow with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Phil Winslow with Wells Fargo.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: I have 2. First, David, if I look at Workspace Services, obviously, you highlight the continued service subscription there, but on a reported basis, you're still up by I think 7% year-over-year. What if you just walk us through some of the demand drivers
componenttext: I have 2. First, David, if I look at Workspace Services, obviously, you highlight the continued service subscription there, but on a reported basis, you're still up by I think 7% year-over-year. What if you just walk us through some of the demand drivers you see in the first half because, obviously, this first half has been a true acceleration apples-to-apples growth. And then just one follow-up to that.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure, Bill. I'm actually really excited about the Workspace right now. Like I've said, we've seen really solid growth in this business on a recognized basis even though 71% of the mix last quarter came via subscription. That's like those numbers, those ar
componenttext: Sure, Bill. I'm actually really excited about the Workspace right now. Like I've said, we've seen really solid growth in this business on a recognized basis even though 71% of the mix last quarter came via subscription. That's like those numbers, those are new product mix and so there's 2 things going on. We have been leading the market for years around desktop virtualization, just pure virtualization. I think that part of the overall business a nice resurgence in the last couple of years because customers are really focused on building and security in those types of opportunities. But really, what's most important for us and probably most exciting is the message that we're driving customers right now about the intelligent Workspace and how we can move those capabilities not just for those focused on virtualization but really add value to everybody inside the enterprise. And we introduced a number of those capabilities and -- at our Synergy conference a couple of months ago we'll be shipping those in the back half of the year so I think our message is resonating, and it will allow us over a long period of time to really expand our available TAM, drive incremental penetration within our installed base and also look for net new customers that really are not using any form of virtualization. So that's where we're taking the product line. That one is clearly leading the subscription transition, and I would expect it to be close to 80% by the end of the year.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just as a follow-up, as you mentioned Synergy, some significant announcements with Microsoft and Synergy including in kind of unofficially announcing the renewal of that partnership if you could just give us an update on just the partners
componenttext: Got it. And then just as a follow-up, as you mentioned Synergy, some significant announcements with Microsoft and Synergy including in kind of unofficially announcing the renewal of that partnership if you could just give us an update on just the partnership with Microsoft and maybe the products that are coming up?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So all partnerships are strong as it's been for 20 years, and that's for a couple of reasons. So one, we have really good alignment in the field where we're working with customers a lot of customers are going to major projects like 0365, Azure transf
componenttext:
Yes. So all partnerships are strong as it's been for 20 years, and that's for a couple of reasons. So one, we have really good alignment in the field where we're working with customers a lot of customers are going to major projects like 0365, Azure transformations, lots of bigger projects, and we can join with Microsoft and really support a lot of those capabilities so that's been very positive. In the longer term, it's just huge opportunity for customers to continue to move their Citrix workflows onto Azure, and that's why it works so well with them. 
Specific to your question about individual products, yes, Brad was with us at Synergy, and we announced a number of new things. For example, the support of their new platform, which they call Windows Virtual Desktop. Now we've integrated that with Citrix Cloud so customers can look at that at as one more place to render workloads giving them really unprecedented flexibility across Citrix Cloud. We also announced the Citrix Managed Desktops, which is really a  service on top of that platform. We're doing that with Microsoft, and we'll be able to bundle Azure capacity a little create a turnkey. We also announced a number of other areas, I'm sure I'm going to forget all of them, but optimization is for Windows -- for Office 365, for SD-WAN. You can do a lot of really cool things to accelerate the performance of Office, optimization for teams, SD-WAN more broadly for Windows Virtual Desktop, adding performance and resiliency as well as a number of other areas. So I'd say the partnership is as broad as any time in my 17 years.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Karl Keirstead with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Karl Keirstead with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to get to the question of, call it, normalized revenue growth. So you posted 1% growth, but you mentioned that there was a 600 to 700 basis point headwind from the mix so, call it, normalized 7%, 8% growth. I think when you gave guidance 3 m
componenttext: I just wanted to get to the question of, call it, normalized revenue growth. So you posted 1% growth, but you mentioned that there was a 600 to 700 basis point headwind from the mix so, call it, normalized 7%, 8% growth. I think when you gave guidance 3 months ago for roughly 3% to 4% growth in 2Q, you were calling for a 200 to 300 basis point hit from the bookings mix, which would equate to normalized growth like 6%, 7%. So my simple math suggests that you were in line or slightly above your prior guide on a normalized basis. I just wanted to check that math and assess whether it's directionally accurate anyway.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: I think your math is exactly right. If you look at the mix shift, I mean it's basically just our prior expectations and the actuals. It's a mix. There's really nothing more to that. Just step back and think about normalized growth rates. I mean what we'
componenttext:
I think your math is exactly right. If you look at the mix shift, I mean it's basically just our prior expectations and the actuals. It's a mix. There's really nothing more to that. 
Just step back and think about normalized growth rates. I mean what we've been executing on if you normalize this whole push to subscription or if you normalize the growth and unbilled revenue so you can really have apples to apples, you look at businesses or companies as a whole it's operating in that mid to high single-digit rate, and that's effectively where we'd be operating on a pure steady-state basis. And as everybody knows, of course, were driving this transition to create much more incremental value long-term for customers stickiness from a product value standpoint. Obviously, that translates into higher returns for investors.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. Maybe a second question. Just on 3Q, your expectation for the subscription bookings mix of 60% to 65% is pretty well in line with what you did in 2Q and yet the revenue guide insist for a 3% decline rather than 1% growth. So the revenue grow
componenttext: Got it. Okay. Maybe a second question. Just on 3Q, your expectation for the subscription bookings mix of 60% to 65% is pretty well in line with what you did in 2Q and yet the revenue guide insist for a 3% decline rather than 1% growth. So the revenue growth decels in 3Q but your subscription bookings mix is quite similar. Maybe it's a complicated answer. I don't know. But why is that, Dave?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, the answer there's always some seasonality in Q3. Not a whole lot more besides that. And then the mix of 60 to 65, not sure exactly where it's going to fall in that range, but I think the rule of thumb that I laid out is a good way for everyone to th
componenttext: Yes, the answer there's always some seasonality in Q3. Not a whole lot more besides that. And then the mix of 60 to 65, not sure exactly where it's going to fall in that range, but I think the rule of thumb that I laid out is a good way for everyone to think about. If you remember when you went into Q2, we had guided the midpoint of at 52%, 52.5% mix. Our revenue outlook would beat [indiscernible] and came in 10 points higher than that so that is revenue so that influences revenue. I think as we go forward, if our mix is a little hotter, that's where we'll come in closer at the bottom of our range and vice versa.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And no one would get upset if I'll ask a third, and I promise I'll stop there. Without stealing the thunder from your September 9th Analyst Day where I'm guessing you'll sort of lay out the transition, the model transition impact on the financials o
componenttext: Okay. And no one would get upset if I'll ask a third, and I promise I'll stop there. Without stealing the thunder from your September 9th Analyst Day where I'm guessing you'll sort of lay out the transition, the model transition impact on the financials over maybe 2020, 2021, Dave, is there any framework you can give us perhaps now on the call about, sort of how long these customers on revs, EPS, cash flow will last? Is it the kind of thing where things should begin to normalize, call it, second half 2020? Any broad framework ahead of the Analyst Day?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're talking about it at a high level. You're right. We do need to talk about those things in the context of a longer discussion so. I think as everybody knows each year, we update long-term targets as we've been moving through this transition, and
componenttext:
Yes, we're talking about it at a high level. You're right. We do need to talk about those things in the context of a longer discussion so. I think as everybody knows each year, we update long-term targets as we've been moving through this transition, and that's based on actual results customer feedback and the outlook. We're going to do that again this year are our analyst meeting in a couple of months, but let's take a bit of a step back for a minute. And so we're 2 years into this transition. I think we made really good progress all in. But unlike other model transitions that we've seen across the industry, we've never really seen any material impact on the P&L up to this point. I think that's been for 2 reasons. First is that we have just a better internal execution, a really good product story so we've sold more. We've sold more and we've just been trying to balance the impact to that point. So phase 1 has been focused really on net new, largely focused So last year, we moved about 42% of the net new subscriptions. This year, as I've said, we're looking at 60%, 65% so that's a big increase. The numbers are now large enough that it's creating this headwind that you're seeing over the course of Q2 and the balance of this year, the really the reported P&L. Again, like I mentioned a minute ago, the offset is going to show up in deferred and unbilled plus these new metrics for everybody has The way I'm thinking about the next couple of years is phase 2 is going to bring much more focus on transitioning on really big installed base. So it started out this year. We've seen a nice uplift in kind of annualized dollars those customers are paying for those we've transitioned so far, and so this is a big incremental opportunity. That's hundreds of millions of dollars annually. That's going to start to become a priority in 2020, and that's why to help understand this, we've delivered these new metrics, unbilled revenue, ARR, in particular, so that everybody can really see how that impacts beyond reported P&L. 
So we'll talk about all that in -- at our next analyst meeting make sure we have complete perspective. Again, we're providing the metrics you can measure along the way, look much more like a traditional subscription transition and looking forward to having that in-depth conversation.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions left here. Just on the point you mentioned of Phase 2 of the transition of the installed base. Any comments you could mention about churn thus far as you can see in these big customers transition and kind of what the level of up
componenttext:
Just a couple of questions left here. Just on the point you mentioned of Phase 2 of the transition of the installed base. Any comments you could mention about churn thus far as you can see in these big customers transition and kind of what the level of uplift is that you're getting on pricing that are staying and kind of what the price realization is? 
And then I just wanted to follow up because I know the question about Microsoft. My question is just more related to Windows 10. There's been some people wondering how much of a driver that's been for the whole Workspace so how does that, that filling -- the to the Windows 10 which has to be done by mid-January, does that become a headwind when you start to think about calendar '20 top line?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me talk about the second question first. I don't hear that much about as a stand-alone driver. I think desktop isn't driver that it would've been for major projects like it was a decade ago. I'd say it's one of the many projects our customers are
componenttext:
Yes. Let me talk about the second question first. I don't hear that much about as a stand-alone driver. I think desktop isn't driver that it would've been for major projects like it was a decade ago. I'd say it's one of the many projects our customers are looking at, and it's one of the things that we can engage in. I'd say that more broadly speaking, when you're talking to customers, every customer meeting I had throughout Q2 was focused, I'd say, first on security on how they're looking at managing an increasingly complex infrastructure; second, on mobility around just finally enabling devices to be used in the enterprise in a secure, simple way across what is usually hundreds of applications in the enterprises. And then the lastly, this idea that a little more about our roadmap and our vision about embracing employee productivity and driving engagement things will just make them -- their teams more productive. And so I'd say, that's probably the bigger driver than any one-off like a Win 10 migration. 
Back to the other question about the installed base. Yes, it's been -- we've actually seen really good success with those customers so far. I'd say it's a limited I wouldn't read too far into it, but the average uplift we saw in Q2 was like 40% from what they have been paying on a typical maintenance contract. And again, that's because it's not just a like-for-like, but this whole migration opportunity is about moving them from what might have been a virtual app sale to a more broad Workspace sale. And so we'll get that uplift as we do that but also provides that platform for us to start expanding more horizontally into untapped that customer so it's really a dual strategy. So we're really happy with what we're seeing so far. We just had to scale that out. It's one of the reasons why we've unified our motions globally now. We have introduced a new COO into the company, an existing employee help focus on really driving this phase 2 in the next couple of years.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Moerdler with Bernstein Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Moerdler with Bernstein Research.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: I really appreciate the fact that you guys are giving more color and the ARR numbers in the breakdown helpful as well as the additional color in the filing. Two questions for you. The first question is while subscription bookings as a percentage of total
componenttext: I really appreciate the fact that you guys are giving more color and the ARR numbers in the breakdown helpful as well as the additional color in the filing. Two questions for you. The first question is while subscription bookings as a percentage of total product bookings was 62% in the quarter, can you give us some color on the percentage of the installed base that is through the subscription? a little color. Is there a sense of what percentage of the base really has moved or really in a point of which the subscription to Citrix Cloud is really from new? Then I have a follow-up.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: So your first question, Mark, [indiscernible] and we're looking at I'd say less than 10% of the installed base has moved at this point in time. one important point to point out is that we are still selling perpetual license to sell the installed base. It'
componenttext: So your first question, Mark, [indiscernible] and we're looking at I'd say less than 10% of the installed base has moved at this point in time. one important point to point out is that we are still selling perpetual license to sell the installed base. It's still moving. It's still growing so it's not static necessarily. But that said, I'd say it's less than 10% at this point. And that's been intentional. I mean we want to make sure that we get this whole process moving around and focused around new new. I think that's important. And once we have that going, you've seen us really driving the business in the last couple of years. This gives us a much better framework to go and drive installed base. And that's also given us an opportunity to really make sure the product sets across Citrix Cloud, across intelligent Workspace and some new initiatives so it's not just a migrate-to-cloud story, it's a much broader opportunity to talk about employee productivity and we can help really drive what, in marketing terms, we call the future of work but holistic strategy to our customers.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up, while Citrix Cloud is cloud, how should we think about its impact on gross margin? Is it more like the subscription where the gross margin is really low? Or is this more like a SaaS? how should we think about it?
componenttext: As a follow-up, while Citrix Cloud is cloud, how should we think about its impact on gross margin? Is it more like the subscription where the gross margin is really low? Or is this more like a SaaS? how should we think about it?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: I'd say it's a good question, Mark. At a high level, our services are not necessarily compete or data-intensive. Therefore, no scale we can manage with pretty high gross margins. That said, as we -- before we get to scale and we're bringing on more and mo
componenttext: I'd say it's a good question, Mark. At a high level, our services are not necessarily compete or data-intensive. Therefore, no scale we can manage with pretty high gross margins. That said, as we -- before we get to scale and we're bringing on more and more customers, I think it's a little bit about there. There's probably a 50 basis point headwind in the first half of the year on gross margins, not big, but it's there. And we obviously have teams that are focused on not just cloud COGS and optimizing that but all of the aspects of cloud operations. And so some there'll be some pressure on gross margins over the years, but we'll manage that. Our services are built out with full multi-tenant and things you would imagine, and so we'll be optimizing across the board.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019

componenttext: I apologize. I never do this. But one quick, can you give a little more color on the NetScaler subscription and what the drivers, what the lift is like? Any more data you can give on that [indiscernible]

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's okay, Mark. It's actually a really interesting dynamic that's happening right now. I'd say I think, as everybody would understand, there are secular changes going on in Networking in general really driven by the adoption of cloud more than anyth
componenttext: Yes, it's okay, Mark. It's actually a really interesting dynamic that's happening right now. I'd say I think, as everybody would understand, there are secular changes going on in Networking in general really driven by the adoption of cloud more than anything else. And so what you've seen over the last quarters is a more pronounced moved to software versus hardware, and that's simply because customers are looking for more flexibility, more choices in a way that they deploy their capabilities. The good news for Citrix, in particular, is that were a software company, and we can deploy our networking hardware in a physical appliance, virtual container, a container as a service and a number of other things, and that's what gives customers flexibility. So the dynamic were seeing right now is the customers that may be in the past would've thought about the hardware refresh cycle, now they're looking at it as a software refresh cycle where buy in our licensing terms our capacity license that can be shared across an on-premise infrastructure, any form of hybrid in the cloud and the container, et cetera, we've got this a great Control Plane and that allows you to help manage that in a reasonably seamless way customers have a lot more flexibility. That's something that we've got unique capabilities, and we're that in the market fairly aggressively, and customers responded. I think 35% of the mix in one quarter is a little higher than I would have expected. That's up from just over 10 a year ago, but that's a trend I expect to continue.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Hedberg with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Hedberg with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: It's Dan Bergstrom for Matt Hedberg. So the acceleration in subscriptions is very impressive. You pointed out some drivers such as hybrid, multi-cloud, Citrix Cloud in your investor letter and prepared remarks here, but could you pinpoint further the chan
componenttext: It's Dan Bergstrom for Matt Hedberg. So the acceleration in subscriptions is very impressive. You pointed out some drivers such as hybrid, multi-cloud, Citrix Cloud in your investor letter and prepared remarks here, but could you pinpoint further the change in pace here versus last quarter? It's really dramatic.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is. We did Q1, we're at 50% of the mix. Q2, we're at 62. And I think the second half of the year, we're going to be pushing 65 or higher to get to that full year of 60, 65. So I mean, we're moving at a pretty rapid pace right now. As I pointed out
componenttext:
Yes, it is. We did Q1, we're at 50% of the mix. Q2, we're at 62. And I think the second half of the year, we're going to be pushing 65 or higher to get to that full year of 60, 65. So I mean, we're moving at a pretty rapid pace right now. As I pointed out, you can see in our letter, 71% of Workspace mix is now coming via subscription. That was up about 10 points from Q1 and 15 points or so year-on-year. That business will continue to move up. Obviously, the gains will start to slow down on an incremental space because And then Networking as it's moved up much more materially from 10 a year ago to 35 now, that's the biggest change. 
We will still continue to sell a fair bit of hardware so I do not expect that in the next 12 months, let's say, to get north of 50%. But I think the rate that we're at right now is probably a pretty good floor, and it'll move up from here. And it's a function of 2 things. I think we have tried as a company to balance of the transition, actively balance that over the last 6, 8 quarters while giving customers the choice that they want. Now we're just embracing it and letting that happen in a bit more of a natural pace, and so you see it's continued the way it was in Q2 and into the back half of the year.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Keith Weiss with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Keith Weiss with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Maybe just to start off in terms of managing the phase 2 of the transition, from an operating margin perspective, is the view that you would just sort of let the transition happen as rapidly as possible take that headwinds on margins up front and kind of
componenttext: Maybe just to start off in terms of managing the phase 2 of the transition, from an operating margin perspective, is the view that you would just sort of let the transition happen as rapidly as possible take that headwinds on margins up front and kind of move, accelerate through the transition to get to a better margin profile down the road? Or is the view that you'll continue to protect margins as you execute your phase 2?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: I think as you see the impact of the top line and certainly the overall growth, I mean that will flow all the way through the P&L. I mean we saw that in Q2 and in our guidance in the second half of the year. I think we've moved margins up a lot in the las
componenttext: I think as you see the impact of the top line and certainly the overall growth, I mean that will flow all the way through the P&L. I mean we saw that in Q2 and in our guidance in the second half of the year. I think we've moved margins up a lot in the last couple of years, and so we're not going to do anything artificial. We're investing to driving to grow the business and drive the transition. We're, of course, always thoughtful and how we manage our expenses and those types of things because we want to make sure that we invest in the right areas, but we absolutely have a view on how we drive long-term sustainable growth. And so I wouldn't expect anything artificial for us in that regard.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Got it. And for the follow-up, in terms of the new metrics that you released this quarter on paid subscriber count. It sounds like we're at 5.4 million today. If I understood you correctly, that's mostly net new. As you think about the maintenance base tr
componenttext: Got it. And for the follow-up, in terms of the new metrics that you released this quarter on paid subscriber count. It sounds like we're at 5.4 million today. If I understood you correctly, that's mostly net new. As you think about the maintenance base transitioning over to cloud, what do you think that number goes to? What do you think is sort of the number of available subscriber count that you have to transition. Is that 5.4 million? Does that increase significantly over the next [indiscernible] Any idea over where that number could go?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: That could go much, much higher, and we'll surely not going to guide that one yet because that's predicated on a few different movements. But if you think about our installed base right now, it is tens and tens of millions of active users, and so the oppo
componenttext: That could go much, much higher, and we'll surely not going to guide that one yet because that's predicated on a few different movements. But if you think about our installed base right now, it is tens and tens of millions of active users, and so the opportunity pool is very material. I think it's premature for us to try and put a number on that right now, but I think we're at the very front end of that broader opportunity.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: This is actually Jaclyn on for Nikolay. So 2 questions. First, can you please give us some concrete examples of how Workspace will close with Windows Virtual Desktop and any areas of current or potential overlap? And my second question is what needs to ha
componenttext: This is actually Jaclyn on for Nikolay. So 2 questions. First, can you please give us some concrete examples of how Workspace will close with Windows Virtual Desktop and any areas of current or potential overlap? And my second question is what needs to happen from a product pricing or go-to-market perspective for the installed base to begin moving to the cloud?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: So there's a couple of questions in there. If you're coming back to the Microsoft question, think about Windows Virtual Desktop as a platform, very similar to the way people of thought about Remote Desktop services over the years, which is part of Windows
componenttext:
So there's a couple of questions in there. If you're coming back to the Microsoft question, think about Windows Virtual Desktop as a platform, very similar to the way people of thought about Remote Desktop services over the years, which is part of Windows I think that's the easiest way to conceptualize it. And so as a platform, it's a multiuser version of Win 10. And so for a lot of our customers, they look at that as maybe a use case that makes sense and part of their business alongside everything else they're trying to accomplish. Our average customers delivering over 500 applications across all different app types and so for us to be able to open up Windows virtual desktop is another resource known or another type of capability that could be managed inside of Citrix Cloud very similar to the way you would be managing, for example, an on-premise application or maybe published SaaS application. So for a lot of customers, that just provides more flexibility. From a platform standpoint, Citrix building a DaaS service on top of that really just embraces and extends a lot of the capabilities to be much more feature-rich on the Enterprise side. So that's probably the easiest way to think about that. It's a component of a broader -- a broader infrastructure from a typical Citrix customer. 
Can you repeat the question about go-to-market?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just curious on what needs to happen from a product or pricing or go-to-market perspective installed base as it begins to move to the cloud.
componenttext: Yes. Just curious on what needs to happen from a product or pricing or go-to-market perspective installed base as it begins to move to the cloud.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Actually, for the most part, the product is there. It's just -- and the pricing is there, and it's just a matter of focusing of point of view. We have different sense of that really some compensation standpoint, not intentionally. I've talked about that e
componenttext: Actually, for the most part, the product is there. It's just -- and the pricing is there, and it's just a matter of focusing of point of view. We have different sense of that really some compensation standpoint, not intentionally. I've talked about that each quarter because teams only have so much bandwidth and wants to have the focus on net new in order to really start building the base. There's a big opportunity around the installed base, and so we'll start expanding that and really leveraging the success we've had in some of the early -- early areas. So I think it's just about making sure we have enough to serve customers, and that's why we've been investing in quota-carrying folks for the last couple of years as well as customer success, and then we'll tweak compensation along the way to make sure we're incenting the right outcomes as we go into 2020 and beyond.

componenttext: David, I have 7 questions. I only have one. Listen, we understand the mix change and its effect on the financials. That all makes sense, but deferred revenue was also lower than expected, and I would have expected that, that would've been much better given the outsized ratable bookings. So can you explain that?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: A few things on deferred. One, you have a -- we had a really big -- if you look back, a really big seasonal comp because we had a megadeal in Q2 a year ago, and that was a large net 8-figure deal. That's one thing. So that's the seasonal play. The other i
componenttext: A few things on deferred. One, you have a -- we had a really big -- if you look back, a really big seasonal comp because we had a megadeal in Q2 a year ago, and that was a large net 8-figure deal. That's one thing. So that's the seasonal play. The other is most of your growth is coming in unbilled right now instead of deferred because the contracts are moving to SaaS. And SaaS are 3-year deals on average, 1-year billed upfront. And that's why we didn't have unbilled a year ago, and now it's $380 million [ adjustment ] and so that's the primary [indiscernible]

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: But I would think that the 1-year deal that you do bill upfront would be more than -- well, I guess, the maintenance that you'd bill, and that would go into deferred. It's still -- you said there were 2 things. Did you say both of them?
componenttext: But I would think that the 1-year deal that you do bill upfront would be more than -- well, I guess, the maintenance that you'd bill, and that would go into deferred. It's still -- you said there were 2 things. Did you say both of them?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: No, I'd point you back to ARR as well, and the reason we did that on a contractual basis: a, it's the adjustment; and b, it gives you the best end-of-quarter visibility into what's really going on. We're going to continue to deliver that on both a total s
componenttext: No, I'd point you back to ARR as well, and the reason we did that on a contractual basis: a, it's the adjustment; and b, it gives you the best end-of-quarter visibility into what's really going on. We're going to continue to deliver that on both a total subscription basis and a SaaS basis. So back there. But all in, deferred and unbilled were up 15% year-on-year, and I'm happy with that. continue to grow in the future.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: David, with the headwinds from the subscription going forward here, does it impact your ability to return capital to shareholders? And if it does, to what effect?
componenttext: David, with the headwinds from the subscription going forward here, does it impact your ability to return capital to shareholders? And if it does, to what effect?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: No. Not materially. I think that when we look at how we have thought about capital return over the years, we have been really consistent. I mean we're always focused, first and foremost, on things that will grow the company. Great M&A at the right price,
componenttext: No. Not materially. I think that when we look at how we have thought about capital return over the years, we have been really consistent. I mean we're always focused, first and foremost, on things that will grow the company. Great M&A at the right price, that's a priority. And when we find those, we execute on that. We also return excess capital via dividends, via share repurchase and that's -- I'm not sure that that's going to change in the future.

componenttext: It's Pete Levine on for Kirk. It's 2 quick ones. Sorry if I missed earlier, but can you give an update on the CEO search? And then the second just to piggyback of the mix shift in the quarter, you talked about it, but just anything that you would call out in the sales or maybe the partner side that accelerated this quarter, major change in guidance there?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: We'll take the second part first. I'd say that with the benefit of hindsight, we've probably been holding it back a little bit in prior quarters what was the normal customer motion, and so we're just letting it happen much more naturally. And I think that
componenttext:
We'll take the second part first. I'd say that with the benefit of hindsight, we've probably been holding it back a little bit in prior quarters what was the normal customer motion, and so we're just letting it happen much more naturally. And I think that's representative of what you're seeing right now. And given the scale of the business, it's time to really and embrace the transition and drive more aggressively. So I'd say that's easiest way to think about that while we want to drive this expectation over the balance of the year and start looking a little bit more like a typical subscription transition that people are used to seeing across companies. 
On the CFO search, it's going well. We've met with a number of external candidates. We have some great internal candidates as well, and we're just going  through the process very methodically. We've got such a solid team right now that I feel comfortable where we are, but I'm more focused on making the right decision than making a quick decision. That said, hopefully, we'll get this wrapped up quickly.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: And it looks like our next question is a follow-up from the line of Phil Winslow with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And it looks like our next question is a follow-up from the line of Phil Winslow with Wells Fargo.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Actually, it's 2 follow-ups. David, you mentioned on the changes in just the market when it comes to the Networking business. With the subscriptions in those changes and how is being delivered, how should we think about the revenue breakeven from the old
componenttext: Actually, it's 2 follow-ups. David, you mentioned on the changes in just the market when it comes to the Networking business. With the subscriptions in those changes and how is being delivered, how should we think about the revenue breakeven from the old product/license model plus maintenance to subscription? And then also, how should we think about the gross margin differential?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, Philip. Gross margin is going to be higher because we're selling software that looks more like it's a typical software gross margin than a hardware gross margins so the probably got a higher gross margin. From a revenue standpoint, you're not selling
componenttext: Yes, Philip. Gross margin is going to be higher because we're selling software that looks more like it's a typical software gross margin than a hardware gross margins so the probably got a higher gross margin. From a revenue standpoint, you're not selling the box along with it so we may have a little bit of lower revenue headwind in the short term, but getting customers to build this out from a the software standpoint I think is going to drive stickiness. So had to go back and look at is probably a little more case-by-case than in the aggregate, but I'd say that breakeven from gross margin and really the extension of gross margin dollars is relatively short term.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2019
componenttextpreview: So thank you, everybody. Again, I appreciate all the multipart questions along the way. I just want to reiterate a couple of things as we go through this. We're driving the business towards a subscription model probably faster than we would've anticipat
componenttext:
So thank you, everybody. Again, I appreciate all the multipart questions along the way. I just want to reiterate a couple of things as we go through this. 
We're driving the business towards a subscription model probably faster than we would've anticipated over the course of the last several quarters. I mean Q2 was a great example of that performance shift with relative to guidance, and that's why we updated the back half of the year. 
We're delivering all these incremental metrics to make sure you can look at the business holistically whether that's ARR, with subscription ARR of 33% of SaaS ARR of nearly 50%. So that was the most important way to lead the business on a go-forward basis. 
Hopefully, everybody can join us at our upcoming analyst meeting the next couple of months. Look forward to seeing you there. And if not, talk to you again in 3 months. Thank you.
